bioghist.p: Rufus King (1755-1827) was a Continental Congressman, Senator, and Minister to Great Britain. Born in Scarboro (then a district of Massachusetts), King graduated from Harvard College in 1777. He served in the Revolutionary War, and then studied law, beginning a practice in Newburyport in 1780. He was a delegate to the Massachusetts General Court, 1783-1785, a member of the Continental Congress from Massachusetts, 1784-1787, a delegate to the Federal constitutional convention at Philadelphia in 1787 and to the State convention in 1788. That year, he moved to New York, where he served as a member of the New York assembly. He was elected to the United States Senate in 1789, reelected in 1795 and served from July 16, 1789, until May 1796, when he resigned to become United States Minister to Great Britain. He returned to the United States in 1803 to run for Vice President as a Federalist candidate, but was unsuccessful. In 1813 he was again elected as a Federalist to the United States Senate in 1813, retaining his seat until 1825. From 1825 to 1826 he served again as United States Minister to Great Britain. King died in New York in 1827. Charles Lennig (b.1810) was the son of Nicholas Lennig and Elise de Boulignez. In 1831 Nicholas and Charles established the Tacony Chemical Works in Port Richmond, one of the first chemical works in the United States.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of correspondence and other documents of Rufus King and several of his descendants, and family papers of the Lennig family. The correspondence of Rufus King, Charles King, Cyrus W. King, and John A. King includes letters from prominent figures such as John Quincy Adams, Daniel Webster, DeWitt Clinton, John Jacob Astor, George Washington, Dorothea Dix, Lafayette, and Alexander Hamilton. The letters consist of invitations, introductions, and diplomatic matters. Other documents related to the King family include: bonds, receipts, an agreement of sale of property, fragments containing signatures, and a document, signed by John Quincy Adams and Henry Clay, sent to King George regarding Rufus King's return to the U.S. The Lennig family papers include correspondence on financial matters between Elise de Boulignez, Elise Lennig, and Nicholas Lennig; a small number of legal documents related to financial matters, and a passport of Charles Lennig. The Lennig correspondence and papers are in French, with a few in German.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
